channel.title: Variety.com
channel.description: The premier source of entertainment news. Turn to Variety.com for timely, credible articles, reviews and analysis of film, TV, music, theater, video, gaming and movie and television production -- information vital to your showbiz career.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2004, Reed Business Information, a division of Reed Elsevier Inc.

item.title: Huelva festival toasts 'Whisky'
item.description: Film News: 'Buenos Aires' takes original screenplay, special jury prizes -- A standout this year at Cannes' Un Certain Regard, Juan Pablo Rebella and Pablo Stoll's "Whisky" took the Golden Columbus pic and director honors at the 30th Huelva Ibero-American Film Festival.

item.title: Bazalgette gets creative at Endemol
item.description: Business News: Co. also names Barnicoat as new COO -- Global production outfit Endemol has appointed Endemol U.K. chairman Peter Bazalgette chief creative officer, effective Jan. 1, taking over from co-founder John de Mol, who left in May.

item.title: D'Onofrio returns to 'Law & Order'
item.description: TV News: Just for Variety: "Law & Order: Criminal Intent," which was shut down for six shooting days due to Vincent D'Onofrio's hospitalization for exhaustion, was back onstage Tuesday with D'Onofrio (Detective Robert Goren) on hand.

item.title: The Aviator
item.description: Film Reviews: An enormously entertaining slice of biographical drama, "The Aviator" flies like one of Howard Hughes' record-setting speed airplanes. While it doesn't dig deeply into the psychology of one of the most famous industrialists and behavioral oddballs of the 20th century, Martin Scorsese's most pleasurable narrative feature in many a year is both extravagant and disciplined, grandly conceived and packed with minutiae.

item.title: 'SVU,' 'Race' set Tuesday pace
item.description: TV News: Morning Ratings Flash - Rick Kissell -- Another strong outing by "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" powered NBC to victory in key demos Tuesday, while CBS reality series "The Amazing Race" again performed well, according to preliminary nationals from Nielsen.

item.title: Weekend Box Office Preview November 24, 2004
item.description: Gotham: 'Treasure' hoping to hold top spot against 'Alexander'

item.title: U shuffles '05 release sked
item.description: Film News: 'Interpreter,' 'Serenity' part of Universal delay -- Universal Pictures has confirmed it has moved back the release date for upcoming Nicole Kidman starrer "The Interpreter," causing a chain reaction of changes to its release sked over the next 12 months.

item.title: HBO makes vid bid for DVD domination
item.description: Business News: Cabler holiday ad campaign's set -- Even with six of the 15 top-selling TV series on DVD this year, HBO Video is aggressively stepping up efforts to increase its homevid domination. This week sees the launch of the company's first major holiday ad campaign for "Oz."

item.title: Icon unveils TV division
item.description: TV News: Move prompted by successful track record -- Having entered TV in a big way this fall, Icon Prods. principals Mel Gibson and Bruce Davey are making it official. The partners have launched a new TV division -- Con Artists Prods. -- along with Icon's Nancy Cotton.

item.title: Downey in the dog house
item.description: Film News: Thesp joins Allen for Disney remake -- Walt Disney Pictures has set Robert Downey Jr. to join Tim Allen in "The Shaggy Dog," the Brian Robbins-directed comic remake about a man who occasionally changes into a sheepdog.

item.title: Race matters
item.description: Letters to the Editor: Letter to the editor

item.title: Civility sidelined
item.description: Los Angeles: Variety editorial -- As sports fans prepare for a weekend of turkey and football, they might wish to forget the images of the NBA brawl in Detroit now being replayed ad nauseum on cable TV.

item.title: Rocking the foreign lingo vote
item.description: Special to Variety: Guest column -- Some of the year's most prominent foreign-lingo films -- "Motorcycle Diaries," "Maria Full of Grace" and "A Very Long Engagement" among them -- won't be eligible for the foreign-language Oscar, thanks to their financing sources or the timing of their overseas release.

item.title: Dobkin gets 'Jack' at NL
item.description: Film News: Helmer to direct, produce pic with Moritz's Original Film -- "Wedding Crashers" helmer David Dobkin and Darren Lemke have sold their action-adventure pitch "Jack" to New Line Cinema. Neal Moritz will produce.

item.title: Viacom's bawdy bill: $3.5 mil
item.description: TV News: FCC accepts indecent proposal from conglom -- Howard Stern is about to get birds-and-bees education on what's indecent -- whether he likes it or not. Wiping the slate mostly clean, Viacom on Tuesday agreed to pay the FCC a record $3.5 million to settle most outstanding indecency claims and related inquiries.

item.title: Pinchot serves up Crystal pix
item.description: Film News: Privately-funded banner has first-look pact with Johnson Group -- Documentary producer Ari Daniel Pinchot, whose latest effort, "Paper Clips," rolls out today , is launching Crystal City Entertainment, a film production and finance company.

item.title: Tag-team on 'Robots'
item.description: Film News: Imax, Fox to release CGI feature in unison -- Imax and 20th Century Fox have pacted to simultaneously release the animated CGI feature "Robots" in both Imax and conventional theaters March 11.

item.title: CBS, Par to 'Ice' LaSalle
item.description: TV News: Thesp will not appear on camera if pilot goes to series -- Eriq La Salle is vying for a TV series return, with the former "ER" star serving as an exec producer via his Humble Journey Films shingle. La Salle and Michael Steinberg have made a pilot script deal with CBS and Paramount for "Ice."

item.title: 'Dr. Phil' to get juicier spots
item.description: TV News: New slot fit for a King -- King World is turning "Dr. Phil" into a rare 7 p.m. show in Detroit, Sacramento and Orlando as part of its three-year renewals through the 2008-09 season.

item.title: Inside Moves: Early releases pay off big for trio
item.description: Music News: Eminem's 'Encore' still No. 1 -- Three albums that saw their release dates moved up will take the top three places on Nielsen SoundScan's tally of the nation's music sales this week.

item.title: Argentine prexy taps culture chief
item.description: Film News: Nun will oversee the National Film Institute -- Argentinian President Nestor Kirchner on Tuesday appointed Jose Nun as culture secretary, a key post for setting policy for financing and regulating film and theater.

item.title: Doubt
item.description: Legit Reviews: All the elements come invigoratingly together like clockwork in John Patrick Shanley's provocative new play, "Doubt," a gripping story of suspicion cast on a priest's behavior that is less about scandal than about fascinatingly nuanced questions of moral certainty.

item.title: Pericles
item.description: Legit Reviews: It is curious that D.C.'s 17-year-old Shakespeare Theater has never produced the Bard's epic "Pericles." Perhaps it has been waiting for director Mary Zimmerman to come along. If so, it was a wise move, since she has an absolute field day with this lavish, calamity-filled voyage that stirs every emotion.

item.title: Pollyanna
item.description: TV Reviews: Masterpiece Theater's presentation of "Pollyanna" seeks to position itself as classic holiday entertainment but is too choppy and disjointed to sweep the audience into the reverie achieved by the best in the genre.

item.title: The 'Seinfeld' Story
item.description: TV Reviews: What's really just an elaborate infomercial for the DVD release takes on a somewhat more exotic flavor upon considering the moribund state of "Must-See TV" comedy that "Seinfeld" once defined. As clip shows go, this one is more self-congratulatory than most, and it gives short shrift to a few key moments in the program's history. That said, there is something fascinating -- certainly for those who don't know the oft-told tale -- about how a comedy that barely made it onto the air eventually became a billion-dollar franchise.

item.title: Shouting match
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: In screener ban's wake, indies are intent on making noise -- There may be small movies at this year's Academy Awards, but there are no small Oscar campaigns. Specialty divisions have dominated much of the year's campaigning, with Warner Independent Pictures kicking it up a notch for "A Very Long Engagement" and Fox Searchlight stumping early and often for "Kinsey" and "Sideways."

item.title: They'll take Manhattan
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: December date catapults indie fete into kudo season -- Is New York's film industry finally getting an awards presentation it can be proud of? After 13 years of playing second fiddle to a host of kudocasts and annual accolades, the Independent Feature Project New York's Gotham Awards is moving into the heat of awards season.

item.title: Screener war vets bond post-ban
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: Indie producers build coalition after triumphing as a unit against MPAA's edict -- "I'm thrilled that this year, screeners are going out," says producer Ted Hope from his cell phone while tooling along a Florida freeway. He is there wrapping his latest film, "The Hawk Is Dying," starring Paul Giamatti. "And it's nice that (the MPAA) did not send out an I'm-your-daddy letter like they did last year."

item.title: Gothams gaga over grads
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: NYU-trained helmers abound at this year's indie bash -- The nominees up for the Gotham Awards' breakthrough director category are an eclectic group whose works stretch from the ghettos of New Jersey to small towns in Colombia. Yet four of the five directors have one thing in common: they all got their master's degrees at New York University.

item.title: Foreign films cross kudo category boundaries
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: Distribs more aggressive in campaigning for major categories -- Spanish helmer Pedro Almodovar's dual Oscar noms (original screenplay and director) for 2002's "Talk to Her"-- a film that was not Spain's foreign-language submission that year -- put the spotlight on what has become an embarrassing trend at the Oscars: Routinely, well-received foreign-language films have a better chance of getting nominated outside their most obvious category.

item.title: Mike Leigh
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: Filmmaker Lifetime Achievement Award -- Today's movie world doesn't offer up many genuine mavericks, which makes one doubly grateful to count English director Mike Leigh among the few. Now 61, the writer-director has been fashioning films (and plays) his way for more than three decades.

item.title: Don Cheadle
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: Gotham Actor Award -- No one can say this year's Gotham actor honoree, Don Cheadle, lacks work. He is in no less than four films this winter -- "Hotel Rwanda," "The Assassination of Richard Nixon," "After the Sunset" and "Ocean's Twelve." And "Hotel Rwanda" has the industry buzzing that Cheadle's breakout time as a leading man is here.

item.title: Dan Talbot
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: Industry Lifetime Achievement Award -- The stealth king of the New York film biz is not a producer, financier or agent. Dan Talbot manages a single asset: the Lincoln Plaza Cinemas. The six-screen venue on Broadway between 62nd and 63rd sits on some of the most valuable real estate in the world.

item.title: Live from New York, it's the Gothams
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: Kudocast strives for balance of panache, indie street cred -- With a set that takes inspiration from a construction zone, it might seem like somebody is trying to lower expectations for the first live broadcast of the Gotham Awards. But that is not the case.

item.title: Pix lining up behind Usher
item.description: Film News: Lions Gate, MGM woo crooner -- Singer-thesp Usher will take on his first dramatic vehicle with Lions Gate Films' "Dying for Dolly," while MGM is trying to line up another Usher project with "Step in the Name of Love."

item.title: Best Feature Nominees
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: Gotham Awards: Best feature nominees

item.title: Documentary Nominees
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: Gotham Awards: Documentary Nominees

item.title: Cossette sings swan song to Grammycast
item.description: TV News: Producer packs it in after 35 years -- February's Grammycast will be the last Pierre Cossette actively produces. After having produced 35 Grammy Awards kudocasts, Cossette will hand the reins to Ken Ehrlich and John Cossette, who will exec produce for Cossette Prods.

item.title: Breakthrough Actors
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: Gotham Awards: Breakthrough Actors

item.title: Breakthrough Directors
item.description: Eye on the Oscars: Indies 2005: Gotham Awards: Breakthrough Directors

item.title: Ebersol family mourns
item.description: TV News: Full recovery for NBC Sports chairman -- NBC Universal said that Dick Ebersol, chairman of NBC Sports, will "make a full recovery" from injuries suffered during a plane crash Nov. 28 that took the life of his son Edward.

item.title: Nair, Filardi will doctor 'Gangsta M.D.' remake
item.description: Film News: 'House' scribe brings flick to life -- Mira Nair has teamed with "Bringing Down the House" scribe Jason Filardi on "Gangsta M.D.," a Bollywood remake that's been set up at 20th Century Fox.

item.title: Thriller pitch crosses Line
item.description: Film News: Flynn, Vinson to produce Laupot script -- New Line Cinema has bought an untitled pitch for Katherine Laupot to write and Contrafilms partners Beau Flynn and Tripp Vinson to produce. New Line veep Michelle Weiss will supervise the paranoid thriller.

item.title: Viv U tech company sale subject of probe
item.description: Business News: Magistrates look into sale of Canal Plus subsid -- The shortcomings of Jean-Marie Messier and other ex-managers at Vivendi Universal have kept Gallic investigators busy, but attention is now turning to Viv U's current toppers and Canal Plus Technologies.

item.title: WGA staffers set vote on unionization
item.description: Business News: Guild could team up with Teamsters -- About 80 staffers at the Writers Guild of America West will vote next week on whether to unionize with the Intl. Brotherhood of Teamsters. A majority yes vote in the Dec. 8 election would place the guild staffers into Teamsters Local 986.

item.title: Narco
item.description: Film Reviews: A narcoleptic nice-guy pursues his dreams in the silly but satisfying "Narco." Those who worry French cinema isn't renewing itself can breathe easier: First feature by Tristan Aurouet and Gilles Lellouche is a sardonic repository of off-kilter humor, jubilant production design and underdog-centered whimsy whose craft matches its originality.

item.title: My Name Is Modesty
item.description: Film Reviews: For a vidpic filmed in 18 days by a helmer hired scarcely a week before the start of principal photography, "My Name Is Modesty" isn't half-bad. This mildly diverting time-killer focuses on the early days of Modesty Blaise, cult-fave heroine of popular novels and comic strips by Brit author Peter O'Donnell.

item.title: Holy Lola
item.description: Film Reviews: A childless French couple determined to adopt an orphan in Cambodia confront emotional, moral and physical obstacles in Bertrand Tavernier's "Holy Lola." Some self-selecting auds may respond; offshore, pic's worthy topic and Tavernier's rep may help it get adopted by some territories.

item.title: Evil Remains
item.description: Film Reviews: Riffing on visual and narrative tropes from "Halloween," "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre," "The Blair Witch Project" and dozens of other, better pics, writer-director James Merendino manages only sporadic scares in "Evil Remains," a small-budget horror opus filmed in and around New Orleans.

item.title: Angels in America
item.description: Legit Reviews: At one point late in the first act of Hungarian composer-librettist team Peter Eotvos and Mari Mezei's English-language opera premiere of "Angels in America," Hannah Pitt (Roberta Alexander), the Mormon mother of closet homosexual Joe (Omar Ebrahim), makes her way up a side aisle of Paris' Chatelet Theater, wondering aloud where she is. Well, audiences familiar with this material, whether through Tony Kushner's singular play or Mike Nichols' deeply empathic HBO telefilm of it, could find themselves asking much the same thing, for somewhat different reasons.

item.title: The Big Con
item.description: Legit Reviews: The audience for "The Big Con" may be limited, but those who like it will find it deeply cathartic. The political mimicry show savages the country's conservative government. Playing Sydney before a slot in Michael Kantor's inaugural season at Melbourne's Malthouse Theater, veteran Max Gillies and twentysomething Eddie Perfect make a formidable duo.

item.title: The Librarian: Quest for the Spear
item.description: TV Reviews: Producer Dean Devlin and company deliver a mildly diverting variation on the oldest of themes, as a nebbishy guy finds himself thrust into the center of a perilous quest. Although hopelessly derivative and not nearly as much fun as it yearns to be, "The Librarian" is just peculiar enough to sustain interest among those who bother to check it out.

item.title: Henry's Film Corner
item.description: TV Reviews: Back when he had only one job -- lead singer of Black Flag -- Henry Rollins oozed the sentiment that if you embrace the music, then you will also embrace the Rollins lifestyle. That notion has only deepened over the past 15 years and while he'll need a little time to get comfortable in the role of an alternative Ebert, the passion is burning in the first 10 segs of "Henry's Film Corner."

item.title: Kekexili: Mountain Patrol (Kekexili)
item.description: Film Reviews: The sympathetic image of Tibetans gets a frank readjustment in "Kekexili: Mountain Patrol," a tough, Western-flavored, true-life yarn about antelope poaching in the region of Kekexili, the last remaining virgin wilderness of Greater China.
